segment.source: When your app handles the Suspending event, it has the opportunity to save its important application data in the handler function.
segment.target: When your app handles the Suspending event, it has the opportunity to save its important application data in the handler function.

segment.source: The app should use the LocalSettings storage API to save simple application data synchronously.
segment.target: The app should use the LocalSettings storage API to save simple application data synchronously.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: The system suspends your app whenever the user switches to another app or to the desktop or Start screen.
segment.target: The system suspends your app whenever the user switches to another app or to the desktop or Start screen.

segment.source: The system resumes your app whenever the user switches back to it.
segment.target: The system resumes your app whenever the user switches back to it.

segment.source: When the system resumes your app, the content of your variables and data structures is the same as it was before the system suspended the app.
segment.target: When the system resumes your app, the content of your variables and data structures is the same as it was before the system suspended the app.

segment.source: The system restores the app exactly where it left off, so that it appears to the user as if it's been running in the background.
segment.target: The system restores the app exactly where it left off, so that it appears to the user as if it's been running in the background.

segment.source: The system attempts to keep your app and its data in memory while it's suspended.
segment.target: The system attempts to keep your app and its data in memory while it's suspended.

segment.source: However, if the system does not have the resources to keep your app in memory, the system will terminate your app.
segment.target: However, if the system does not have the resources to keep your app in memory, the system will terminate your app.

segment.source: When the user switches back to a suspended app that has been terminated, the system sends an Activated event and should restore its application data in its OnLaunched method.
segment.target: When the user switches back to a suspended app that has been terminated, the system sends an Activated event and should restore its application data in its OnLaunched method.

segment.source: The system doesn't notify an app when it's terminated, so your app must save its application data and release exclusive resources and file handles when it's suspended, and restore them when the app is activated after termination.
segment.target: The system doesn't notify an app when it's terminated, so your app must save its application data and release exclusive resources and file handles when it's suspended, and restore them when the app is activated after termination.

segment.source: Note If you need to do asynchronous work when your app is being suspended you will need to defer completion of suspend until after your work completes.
segment.target: Note If you need to do asynchronous work when your app is being suspended you will need to defer completion of suspend until after your work completes.

segment.source: You can use the GetDeferral method on the SuspendingOperation object (available via the event args) to delay completion of suspend until after you call the Complete method on the returned SuspendingDeferral object.
segment.target: You can use the GetDeferral method on the SuspendingOperation object (available via the event args) to delay completion of suspend until after you call the Complete method on the returned SuspendingDeferral object.

segment.source: Note To improve system responsiveness in Windows 8.1, apps are given low priority access to resources after they are suspended.
segment.target: Note To improve system responsiveness in Windows 8.1, apps are given low priority access to resources after they are suspended.

segment.source: To support this new priority, the suspend operation timeout is extended so that the app has the equivalent of the 5-second timeout for normal priority on Windows or between 1 and 10 seconds on Windows Phone.
segment.target: To support this new priority, the suspend operation timeout is extended so that the app has the equivalent of the 5-second timeout for normal priority on Windows or between 1 and 10 seconds on Windows Phone.

segment.source: You cannot extend or alter this timeout window.
segment.target: You cannot extend or alter this timeout window.

segment.source: A note about debugging using Visual Studio: Visual Studio prevents Windows from suspending an app that is attached to the debugger.
segment.target: A note about debugging using Visual Studio: Visual Studio prevents Windows from suspending an app that is attached to the debugger.

segment.source: This is to allow the user to view the Visual Studio debug UI while the app is running.
segment.target: This is to allow the user to view the Visual Studio debug UI while the app is running.

segment.source: When you're debugging an app, you can send it a suspend event using Visual Studio.
segment.target: When you're debugging an app, you can send it a suspend event using Visual Studio.

segment.source: Make sure the Debug Location toolbar is being shown, then click the Suspend icon.
segment.target: Make sure the Debug Location toolbar is being shown, then click the Suspend icon.
